children.value: In this section we will examine the disassembly of a simple C program that divides two integers. The program is compiled for the i386 architecture, which is a 32-bit architecture commonly used in older computers and embedded systems. The disassembly will help us understand how the C code translates into assembly instructions, and how these instructions are executed by the CPU.
Compilation of the C Program to Produce Assembly Code and Object Code

children.label: Compilation of the C Program to Produce Assembly Code and Object Code

children.value: The C program is compiled using the GCC compiler with the
flag to specify the i386 architecture. The
flag creates assembly code in the Intel format. The
flag includes C source code in the assembly code, and the
flag compiles the assembly code into an object file.

gcc --sysroot=/ -m32 -masm=intel -S -fverbose-asm div_int.c -o div_int.s
gcc --sysroot=/ -m32 -c div_int.s -o div_int.o
The assembly code is in Intel syntax, which is commonly used for x86 assembly language.

.file	"div_int.c"
	.intel_syntax noprefix
# GNU C17 (conda-forge gcc 14.2.0-2) version 14.2.0 (x86_64-conda-linux-gnu)
#	compiled by GNU C version 14.2.0, GMP version 6.2.1, MPFR version 4.1.0, MPC version 1.2.1, isl version isl-0.24-GMP

# GGC heuristics: --param ggc-min-expand=100 --param ggc-min-heapsize=131072
# options passed: -m32 -masm=intel -mtune=generic -march=x86-64
	.text
	.globl	main
	.type	main, @function
main:
.LFB0:
	.cfi_startproc
	push	ebp	#
	.cfi_def_cfa_offset 8
	.cfi_offset 5, -8
	mov	ebp, esp	#,
	.cfi_def_cfa_register 5
	sub	esp, 16	#,
	call	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax	#
	add	eax, OFFSET FLAT:_GLOBAL_OFFSET_TABLE_	# tmp98,
# div_int.c:7: 	a = 10;
	mov	DWORD PTR -4[ebp], 10	# a,
# div_int.c:8: 	b = 5;
	mov	DWORD PTR -8[ebp], 5	# b,
# div_int.c:10: 	c = a / b;
	mov	eax, DWORD PTR -4[ebp]	# tmp104, a
	cdq
	idiv	DWORD PTR -8[ebp]	# b
	mov	DWORD PTR -12[ebp], eax	# c, c_3
	mov	eax, 0	# _4,
# div_int.c:11: }
	leave	
	.cfi_restore 5
	.cfi_def_cfa 4, 4
	ret	
	.cfi_endproc
.LFE0:
	.size	main, .-main
	.section	.text.__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax,"axG",@progbits,__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax,comdat
	.globl	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax
	.hidden	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax
	.type	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax, @function
__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax:
.LFB1:
	.cfi_startproc
	mov	eax, DWORD PTR [esp]	#,
	ret
	.cfi_endproc
.LFE1:
	.ident	"GCC: (conda-forge gcc 14.2.0-2) 14.2.0"
	.section	.note.GNU-stack,"",@progbits
The attached code is an assembly file (
) using the GCC compiler. It is written in Intel syntax and targets the x86 architecture in 32-bit mode (
). Below is a detailed explanation of the code:
Indicates that this assembly file was generated from the source file
Specifies that the assembly code uses Intel syntax (as opposed to AT&T syntax) and does not require prefixes like
The code was compiled using GCC version 14.2.0.
It includes information about the compilerâ€™s configuration, such as GMP, MPFR, and MPC versions, as well as the target architecture (
The options used during compilation include:
: Optimize for a generic x86 processor.
The main function is defined as a global symbol (
) and is marked as a function (
The prologue sets up the stack frame for the function:
) of the caller function onto the stack.
) to the value of the stack pointer (
Allocates 16 bytes of space on the stack for local variables.
Calls a helper function to get the program counter (PC) value.
Adjusts the PC value to point to the Global Offset Table (GOT), which is used for position-independent code.
The C code initializes three variables:
. These are represented as local variables on the stack:
The C code performs the division
to a 64-bit value by sign-extending it into the
pair. This is required for signed division.
, and the remainder is stored in
Stores the result of the division (the quotient,
Sets the return value of the function to
The epilogue restores the stack frame and returns control to the caller:
Pops the old base pointer from the stack into
Returns control to the caller by popping the return address from the stack.
This function is used to retrieve the program counter (PC) value for position-independent code:
Loads the return address (stored at the top of the stack) into the
Contains a string identifying the compiler version used to generate the assembly code.
Marks the stack as non-executable, which is a security feature.
This assembly code implements a simple C program that initializes two integers (
. The code is optimized for 32-bit x86 architecture and includes standard prologue and epilogue for stack management.
The object file is linked to create an executable file using the
The executable file is disassembled using the

objdump -x -D -s -t -Mintel div_int.o > objdump_of_dot_o.txt
objdump -x -D -s -t -Mintel div_int_C_i386 > objdump_of_dot_exe.txt
Explanation of the Switches used in the

The attached file is the output of the
tool, which is used to analyze binary files. Specifically, this is the disassembly of an object file named
architecture. Below is a detailed explanation of the fileâ€™s contents:
The first few lines provide metadata about the object file:
indicates the file is in the ELF (Executable and Linkable Format) for the 32-bit Intel x86 architecture.
indicates the file has relocation entries (
is the entry point address (not relevant for object files, as they are not executable).
The object file is divided into sections, each serving a specific purpose. The table lists the sections with their attributes:
Purpose: Groups related sections for optimization (e.g.,
ensures duplicate sections are discarded during linking).
CONTENTS, ALLOC, LOAD, RELOC, READONLY, CODE
Purpose: Stores initialized global and static variables.
Purpose: Stores uninitialized global and static variables.
Purpose: Contains a helper function for position-independent code (PIC).
Purpose: Marks the stack as non-executable (security feature).
Purpose: Stores metadata about the binary (e.g., ABI compatibility).
Purpose: Stores exception handling information (used for stack unwinding).
CONTENTS, ALLOC, LOAD, RELOC, READONLY, DATA
The symbol table lists symbols (functions, variables, etc.) defined or referenced in the object file:
The contents of each section are displayed in hexadecimal and disassembled into assembly instructions.

00000000 <main>:
   0: 55                    push   ebp
   1: 89 e5                 mov    ebp,esp
   3: 83 ec 10              sub    esp,0x10
   6: e8 fc ff ff ff        call   7 <main+0x7>
   b: 05 01 00 00 00        add    eax,0x1
  10: c7 45 fc 0a 00 00 00  mov    DWORD PTR [ebp-0x4],0xa
  17: c7 45 f8 05 00 00 00  mov    DWORD PTR [ebp-0x8],0x5
  1e: 8b 45 fc              mov    eax,DWORD PTR [ebp-0x4]
  21: 99                    cdq
  22: f7 7d f8              idiv   DWORD PTR [ebp-0x8]
  25: 89 45 f4              mov    DWORD PTR [ebp-0xc],eax
  28: b8 00 00 00 00        mov    eax,0x0
  2d: c9                    leave
  2e: c3                    ret
Stores the result in another local variable.
Contains a helper function for position-independent code:
Relocation entries are present in the
: Relocation for the Global Offset Table (GOT).
The disassembly of each section shows the machine instructions and their corresponding assembly code. For example:
Retrieves the program counter for position-independent code.
) contains a simple program that performs integer division. It is compiled for the 32-bit x86 architecture and includes metadata, code, and relocation entries. The
) and stores the result. The file also includes helper functions and metadata for position-independent code and exception handling.
Project code and resources can be found on my GitHub repository:
